articles.description: While reverse engineering a Linux binary, I ran into a fairly common situation: I wanted to understand how a decompression function works, but I didn‚Äôt have compressed data to test with. In this blog, I‚Äôll look at how to we can manipulate the instruction pointer in the GNU debugger (gdb) to trick the software into generating test data for us! I posted this on Mastodon awhile back, but I cleaned it up and expanded it a bit to make it a full blog post.
articles.title: GDB Tricks: Tricking the Application into Generating Test Data

articles.author: Scott Sutherland
articles.description:
By default, PowerShell is configured to prevent the execution of PowerShell scripts on Windows systems. In this blog I‚Äôll cover 15 ways to bypass the PowerShell execution policy without having local administrator rights on the system.
The post 15 Ways to Bypass the PowerShell Execution Policy appeared first on NetSPI.
articles.title: 15 Ways to Bypass the PowerShell Execution Policy

articles.description: In this blog post, I show how you can combine my tools zipdump.py, file-magic.py and myjson-filter.py to select and analyze files of a particular type. I start with a daily batch of malware files published by Malware Bazaar. I let it produce JSON output using option ‚Äìjsonoutput, that can be consumed by some of my [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Combining zipdump, file-magic And myjson-filter

articles.author: Didier Stevens
articles.description: A small update to option -W of zipdump.py. Next to value vir, you can now also specify values hash and hashvir. hash: write each file with name equal to the SHA256 of the content of the file. hashvir: write each file with name equal to the SHA256 of the content of the file plus extension [‚Ä¶]

articles.description: There are powerstrips with a switch that lights up when the switch is turned on. Like this one: These switches (certainly older models) often use a neon lamp as light source. I measured the electric energy consumption of a powerstrip with switch on and neon lamp burning (without anything plugged into the powerstrip‚Äôs outlets). It [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Powerstrip With Neon Lamp Switch

articles.description: I use my tools dns-pydivert and dnsresolver.py for dynamic analysis of software (malware and benign software). On the virtual machine where I‚Äôm doing dynamic analysis, I disable IPv6 support. I install dnslib and run dnsresolver.py with a command like this, for example: The first command is a resolve command: DNS A queries for example.com will [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Combining dns-pydivert And dnsresolver

articles.author: Didier Stevens
articles.description: dns-pydivert is a tool that uses WinDivert, a ‚Äúuser-mode packet capture-and-divert package for Windows‚Äù to divert IPv4 DNS packets to and from the machine it is running on. This tool requires admin rights. When started, it listens for IPv4 UDP packets with source and/or destination port equal to 53.When this tools processes its first UDP [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: New Tool: dns-pydivert.py

articles.description: This new version brings extra statistics with option -f (fullread): counter for unique bytes, control bytes, printable bytes, high bytes. And lengths of the longest ASCII string, ASCII hexadecimal string and ASCII base64 string. Remark that no check is made for hex string length being a multiple of 2 and base64 string length being a [‚Ä¶]

articles.author: Didier Stevens
articles.description: This new tool, teeplus.py, is an extension of the tee command. The tools takes (binary) data from stdin, and sends it to stdout, while also writing the data to a file on disk. While the tee command requires a filename as argument, teeplus.py takes no arguments (only options). By default, teeplus.py will write the data [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: New tool: teeplus.py

articles.author: Didier Stevens
articles.description: Option -W can be used to write all files to disk. The only accepted value for -W is vir (for the moment). When this option is provided, all files are written to the local disk (ignoring contained paths) with their original name, and appended extension .vir. To print out properties line per line, use separator [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Update: zipdump.py Version 0.0.23

articles.author: Brian Gorenc
articles.description:
Jump to the contest rules
Last year, we celebrated the 15th anniversary of Pwn2Own with a spectacular contest. We awarded more than $1,000,000 USD for the amazing research demonstrated. That makes us even more excited to return to Vancouver for the 2023 edition of Pwn2Own. Similar to last year, we‚Äôll be holding a hybrid conference with most of us in person at the Sheraton Wall Center in Vancouver for the CanSecWest conference on March 22-24, 2023. The other part of the hybrid event means that we also allow remote participation. If you have either travel restrictions or travel safety concerns, you can opt to compete remotely. 
We‚Äôre also excited to have Tesla return as a partner. They always innovate, and we‚Äôve updated our target list to keep up. We‚Äôve added a Steam VM Escape category with ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Announcing Pwn2Own Vancouver for 2023

articles.author: Dustin Childs
articles.description:
Welcome to the first patch Tuesday of the new year. As expected, Adobe and Microsoft have released their latest fixes and updates. Take a break from your regularly scheduled activities and join us as we review the details of their latest security offerings.
Adobe Patches for January 2023
For January, Adobe released four patches addressing 29 CVEs in Adobe Acrobat and Reader, InDesign, InCopy, and Adobe Dimension. A total of 22 of these bugs were submitted through the ZDI program. The update for Reader fixes 15 bugs with eight of these being ranked Critical in severity. The most severe of these would allow arbitrary code execution if an affected system opened a specially crafted file. The patch for InDesign fixes six bug, four of which are rated Critical. Similar to the Reader patch, openin‚Ä¶
articles.title: The January 2023 Security Update Review

articles.author: Dustin Childs
articles.description:
We‚Äôve successfully orbited our star once more and are full throttle into the new year. We‚Äôve just completed our largest Pwn2Own ever in Toronto and are only six weeks away from Pwn2Own Miami, but before we go too far into 2023, now is a good time to look at some of the numbers and highlights of the past year.
These are a Few of My Favorite Bugs
It‚Äôs always great to see the huge number of amazing bugs submitted by independent researchers around the globe, but some really stood out. We‚Äôre super thankful for our global community of independent researchers, and we congratulate the 23 researchers to achieve reward levels in 2022. We had five people reach Platinum status, five reach Gold, seven Silver, and six Bronze. The work and submissions from our community of independent researchers are key‚Ä¶
articles.title: Looking Back at the Bugs of 2022

articles.author: Brian Gorenc
articles.description:
Last week, we completed our largest Pwn2Own contest ever. We saw 66 entries over four days and witnessed some amazing research resulting in $989,750 USD for 63 unique 0-days. However, leading up to the event was anything but smooth sailing on calm seas. Here‚Äôs the wrap video summarizing the event:
When we published the rules, we anticipated quite a bit of interest in both the routers and the SOHO Smashup targets. What we didn‚Äôt expect was 85 entries overall. To put some perspective on that number, in 2017, we had 13 total entries in what was (at the time) our largest event ever. We‚Äôve had some growth. 
While we were struggling to find a way to run that many attempts in three days, the first of several patches appeared. Most notably, NETGEAR released a fix specifically targeting bugs that w‚Ä¶
articles.title: Behind the Scenes of Pwn2Own Toronto 2022

articles.title: Protected: Investigating Filter Communication Ports

articles.description:
This is my write-up for the SANS Holiday Hack Challenge 2022.
Main Objectives
The first part of the objective is an introduction where you are told about how your badge work, how the terminal works and a tutorial on setting up your wallet. It also establishes the backstory and sends you down in the underground tunnels. After this is completed there are five main objective chapters, each containing a few challenges.
Recover the Tolkien Ring
The first chapter is to recover the Tolkien Ring. This chapter revolves around DFIR.
Wireshark Practice
The first challenge is a terminal where you get a PCAP and need to answer a few questions about the traffic.
To answer the first question, we look at the traffic, see that there is a lot of HTTP traffic and then go to File -> Export objects -> HTTP to ‚Ä¶
articles.title: SANS Holiday Hack Challange 2022: Writeup

articles.description:
The computer science chapter at my alma mater, KTH, arranges an advent calendar called ‚ÄúdJulkalendern‚Äù.
It is a CTF-like puzzle with challenges (almost) every day until christmas and also a competition.
The puzzles are not really security focused like regular CTF but more broader IT related puzzles.
This year, there were a puzzle every weekday and I will go through and explain them all.
To prevent this post from being too long, I will be pretty brief in my explanations. If you have any questions or solved something in a different way, please comment below.
Day -1: Ready?
The first window is simply a warm-up and encourages you to read the lore page to get the backstory and create some hype before the challenges begin.
It also introduces how the password system works by giving you the passwo‚Ä¶
articles.title: dJulkalender 2022: Write-up

articles.author: emmaline
articles.description:
During August 2022 we published a blog discussing AWS Security Trends of 2022 , one of which was ABAC in Lambda. AWS allows administrators to use tags to designate attributes for both IAM and AWS resources. Attribute Based Access Control, or ABAC, is a strategy to allow permissions assignment based on the value of such [‚Ä¶]
The post ABAC in Lambda appeared first on Praetorian.
articles.title: ABAC in Lambda

articles.author: emmaline
articles.description:
Building a security program from the ground up is a complicated, complex undertaking that can pay massive dividends down the road. We firmly believe that ‚Äúthe devil is in the details,‚Äù in that the more thought an organization invests in organizing their framework (see Part 1 of this series) and planning how to measure against [‚Ä¶]
The post Doing the Work: How to Architect a Systematic Security Program, Part 3 appeared first on Praetorian.
articles.title: Doing the Work: How to Architect a Systematic Security Program, Part 3

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By William Woodruff Read the official announcement on the Sigstore blog as well! Trail of Bits is thrilled to announce the first stable release of sigstore-python, a client implementation of Sigstore that we‚Äôve been developing for nearly a year! This work has been graciously funded by Google‚Äôs Open Source Security Team (GOSST), who we‚Äôve also [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Announcing a stable release of sigstore-python

articles.author: tobgreg
articles.description: By Max Ammann Trail of Bits is publicly disclosing four vulnerabilities that affect wolfSSL: CVE-2022-38152, CVE-2022-38153, CVE-2022-39173, and CVE-2022-42905. The four issues, which have CVSS scores ranging from medium to critical, can all result in a denial of service (DoS). These vulnerabilities have been discovered automatically using the novel protocol fuzzer tlspuffin. This blog post [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Keeping the wolves out of wolfSSL

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By Samuel Moelius This time last year, we wrote about the more than 190 Trail of Bits-authored pull requests that were merged into non-Trail of Bits repositories in 2021. In 2022, we continued that trend by having more than 400 pull requests merged into non-Trail of Bits repositories! Why is this significant? While we take [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Another prolific year of open-source contributions

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By Nick Selby Trail of Bits recently completed a security review of cURL, which is an amazing and ubiquitous tool for transferring data. We were really thrilled to see cURL founder and lead developer Daniel Stenberg write a blog post about the engagement and the report, and wanted to highlight some important things he pointed [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: How to share what you‚Äôve learned from our audits

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By Mate Kukri The naive approach to searching for patterns in source code is to use regular expressions; a better way is to parse the code with a custom parser, but both of these approaches have limitations. During my internship, I prototyped an internal tool called Syntex that does searching on Clang ASTs to avoid [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Fast and accurate syntax searching for C and C++

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: A Primer on Process Reparenting in Windows By Yarden Shafir Process reparenting is a technique used in Microsoft Windows to create a child process under a different parent process than the one making the call to CreateProcess. Malicious actors can use this technique to evade security products or break process ancestry ties, making detection more [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: What child is this?

articles.author: Exodus Intel VRT
articles.description:
EIP-ad32d249 A local privilege escalation vulnerability exists in the¬†CloudLinux Lightweight Virtualized Environment (LVE) kernel module due to an overflow of a reference counter. Successful exploitation allows an authenticated local user to escalate their privileges to root, whereas an unsuccessful exploit may cause a kernel panic.¬† Vulnerability Identifiers Exodus Intelligence: EIP-ad32d249 MITRE: CVE-2022-0492 Vulnerability Metrics CVSSv2 ... Read more CloudLinux LVE kernel module (kmod-lve) Reference Counter Overflow
The post CloudLinux LVE kernel module (kmod-lve) Reference Counter Overflow appeared first on Exodus Intelligence.
articles.title: CloudLinux LVE kernel module (kmod-lve) Reference Counter Overflow

articles.author: Exodus Intel VRT
articles.description:
EIP-6a6472ab A remote code execution vulnerability exists in SonicWall SMA 100 Series and SMA 500v Series due to a heap buffer overflow in the ‚Äòextensionsetting‚Äô endpoint. A remote, authenticated attacker can send crafted HTTP POST requests to execute code on vulnerable targets as the ‚Äònobody‚Äô user. Vulnerability Identifiers Exodus Intelligence: EIP-6a6472ab MITRE: CVE-2022-2915 Vulnerability Metrics ... Read more SonicWall SMA 500v and SMA 100 Series Firmware Heap Buffer Overflow
The post SonicWall SMA 500v and SMA 100 Series Firmware Heap Buffer Overflow appeared first on Exodus Intelligence.
articles.title: SonicWall SMA 500v and SMA 100 Series Firmware Heap Buffer Overflow

articles.author: Exodus Intel VRT
articles.description:
EIP-50a1e402 An information disclosure vulnerability exists in Schneider Electric SoMachine HVAC due to a method in the ‚ÄòAxEditGrid3.ocx‚Äô ActiveX control leaking a heap address of an ActiveX object. An attacker can entice a user to open a specially crafted web page to leak Internet Explorer process memory information. Vulnerability Identifiers Exodus Intelligence: EIP-50a1e402 MITRE: CVE-2022-2988 ... Read more Schneider Electric SoMachine HVAC ActiveX Control Information Disclosure Vulnerability
The post Schneider Electric SoMachine HVAC ActiveX Control Information Disclosure Vulnerability appeared first on Exodus Intelligence.
articles.title: Schneider Electric SoMachine HVAC ActiveX Control Information Disclosure Vulnerability

articles.author: Exodus Intel VRT
articles.description:
By Sergi Martinez Overview It‚Äôs been a while since our last technical blogpost, so here‚Äôs one right on time for the Christmas holidays. We describe a method to exploit a use-after-free in the Linux kernel when objects are allocated in a specific slab cache, namely the kmalloc-cg series of SLUB caches used for cgroups. This ... Read more Linux Kernel: Exploiting a Netfilter Use-after-Free in kmalloc-cg
The post Linux Kernel: Exploiting a Netfilter Use-after-Free in kmalloc-cg appeared first on Exodus Intelligence.
articles.title: Linux Kernel: Exploiting a Netfilter Use-after-Free in kmalloc-cg

articles.author: Andy Gill
articles.description:
Hello Everyone, 
This a short blog post to announce I have finally published my second book after several years of work. I have spent nearly five writing it; like my first one, it follows the path of getting into and progressing in the industry, while LTR101 was focused on bug
articles.title: LTR102 - Published Finally!

articles.author: Surender Kumar
articles.description:
In my previous post, you learned how to get started with Proxmox VE as an alternative to VMware and Hyper-V. In that post, I covered how to run your first Linux VM in Proxmox. Today, I will show you how to create a Windows VM in Proxmox. This may sound like a straightforward task, but there are certain settings in Proxmox VE that are worth checking out to make sure you get better performance in Windows. If you install Windows with the default Proxmox settings, you will likely experience poor performance.
Create a Windows VM in Proxmox VE first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Create a Windows VM in Proxmox VE

articles.author: Karthick Jokirathinam
articles.description:
The Microsoft Endpoint Configuration Manager 2211 production version was released on December 6, 2022, in the early update ring. In this post, we will go through the new features in version 2211, followed by a step-by-step guide to upgrade the Configuration Manager.
Configuration Manager upgrade: New features and installation first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Configuration Manager upgrade: New features and installation

articles.author: Timothy Warner
articles.description:
Learn how to assess and migrate your on-prem SQL Server databases to Azure SQL Database by using Microsoft's Data Migration Assistant and Azure Migrate products.
Migrate a SQL Server Database to Azure SQL Database first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Migrate a SQL Server Database to Azure SQL Database

articles.author: Brandon Lee
articles.description:
Many people use VMware Workstation to set up lab environments. The first step in getting vSphere 8 with a vSphere cluster running is to install the vCenter Server Appliance (vCSA). Let's see how we can deploy vCenter Server 8 in VMware Workstation.
Install vCenter 8 in VMware Workstation first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Install vCenter 8 in VMware Workstation

articles.author: Surender Kumar
articles.description:
In a previous post, we discussed how to quickly unlock AD accounts with PowerShell. However, the main problem admins tend to face is identifying the source computer or service that is causing the account to lock out in the first place.
Find the source of AD account lockouts first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Find the source of AD account lockouts

articles.author: Timothy Warner
articles.description:
Learn how the AI-powered GitHub Copilot pair programming engine can accelerate your Windows administration work by providing intelligent suggestions while you type.
GitHub Copilot for the Windows systems administrator first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: GitHub Copilot for the Windows systems administrator

articles.author: Steve Buchanan
articles.description:
Draft is an open-source project that helps developers go from a noncontainerized application to running on Kubernetes with ease. As a developer with Draft, you don't have to go through an extensive ramp of containers, container registries, Kubernetes, and deployment methods to get your app running as a container on Azure Kubernetes.
Draft: Containerize apps for Azure Kubernetes Service first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Draft: Containerize apps for Azure Kubernetes Service

articles.author: Surender Kumar
articles.description:
IT admins or helpdesk teams often use graphical tools, such as Active Directory Users and Computers (ADUC), to unlock AD accounts. However, it is usually easier to unlock multiple AD accounts with PowerShell.
Unlock AD accounts with PowerShell first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Unlock AD accounts with PowerShell

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
In addition to the simple, purely local spell checker, the two Chromium-based web browsers, Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge, also offer an advanced spell checker that sends texts entered in web applications to the cloud. This can be turned off interactively or by group policy.
Privacy: Disable cloud-based spell checker in Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Privacy: Disable cloud-based spell checker in Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge

articles.author: Leos Marek
articles.description:
PsLoggedOn, a command line tool that is part of the Sysinternals suite, gets information about users logged on to Windows. Unfortunately, not everything works as it should.
PsLoggedOn: View logged-on users in Windows first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: PsLoggedOn: View logged-on users in Windows

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
If you take a look at the group policy settings in Windows 11 or the separately available ADMX files, you will find settings for Microsoft Edge there. However, they do not affect the Chromium-based browser. For this version, you have to download and install the administrative templates separately.
Download and install ADMX templates for Microsoft Edge first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Download and install ADMX templates for Microsoft Edge

articles.author: Surender Kumar
articles.description:
At some point, admins need to pick a suitable virtualization solution that best aligns with their existing server infrastructure. This post will focus on comparing three hypervisors: Proxmox VE, VMware ESXi, and Hyper-V.
Proxmox VE vs. VMware ESXi vs. Hyper-V first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Proxmox VE vs. VMware ESXi vs. Hyper-V

articles.author: Timothy Warner
articles.description:
Learn the many ways you can make your Microsoft Azure work easier by integrating with Visual Studio Code (VS Code), Microsoft's free, open-source, cross-platform code editor.
Work in Microsoft Azure with Visual Studio Code (VS Code) first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Work in Microsoft Azure with Visual Studio Code (VS Code)

articles.author: Brandon Lee
articles.description:
VirtualBox provides an effective and free solution for running ESXi in a lab environment. However, at this point, the support for nested virtualization doesn't allow the installation of current versions of VMware's hypervisor. As with Hyper-V VMs, a nested configuration is limited to ESXi 6.x. If you need to enable Microsoft's hypervisor on a Windows PC, VirtualBox can run on top of it.
Install ESXi in a VirtualBox VM first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Install ESXi in a VirtualBox VM

articles.author: Leos Marek
articles.description:
PsKill is a command-line tool that is part of the Sysinternals suite. As the name suggests, it allows you to terminate (kill) Windows processes on local or remote Windows systems.
Terminate Windows processes with PsKill first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Terminate Windows processes with PsKill

articles.author: Karthick Jokirathinam
articles.description:
You can install Microsoft apps with Intune and receive updates whenever a new version is released. Intune can also automatically update Microsoft apps. The Microsoft Store supports UWP apps, desktop applications packaged as .msix, and Win32 apps packaged as .exe or .msi installers. You can browse the apps in Intune and install or uninstall them.
Install Microsoft apps with Intune first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Install Microsoft apps with Intune

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
Controlled folder access prevents suspicious programs from modifying or creating files in protected directories, such as Documents, Pictures, Favorites, or Desktop. The feature can be configured centrally via group policies, for example, to allow access to additional apps.
Controlled folder access: Configure ransomware protection with Group Policy and PowerShell first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Controlled folder access: Configure ransomware protection with Group Policy and PowerShell

articles.author: Brandon Lee
articles.description:
ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus is a fully featured solution to easily implement self-service password reset, SSO, password synchronization, MFA, and an employee directory while enforcing strong password policies.
Self-service password reset with ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Self-service password reset with ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus

articles.author: Surender Kumar
articles.description:
Are you looking for a virtualization alternative to Microsoft Hyper-V and VMware ESXi? Proxmox VE is a Debian-based opensource alternative virtualization solution with a custom Linux kernel that you can use to virtualize bare-metal servers in your enterprise. It uses kernel-based virtual machine (KVM) virtualization technology for virtual machines and Linux Containers (LXC) for containers, allowing you to create and manage VMs, containers, storage, virtualized networks, clusters, and much more. This post shows how you can install the Proxmox Virtualization Environment (VE).
Proxmox VE: Virtualization alternative to VMware ESXi and Hyper-V first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Proxmox VE: Virtualization alternative to VMware ESXi and Hyper-V

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
While DES has long been considered insecure, CVE-2022-37966 accelerates the departure of RC4 for the encryption of Kerberos tickets. If you have not explicitly assigned an algorithm to accounts, then AES will be used in the future. You can use PowerShell to determine which accounts are vulnerable to weak encryption.
Find Active Directory accounts configured for DES and RC4 Kerberos encryption first appeared on 4sysops.
articles.title: Find Active Directory accounts configured for DES and RC4 Kerberos encryption

articles.description:
There is a combination of lesser known tools and techniques to capture and later decrypt SSL/TLS network traffic on Windows. This technique is neat because it does not require the installation of additional driver/software when capturing the traffic.
Technique, Tools and Steps It is quite straight forward and consists of:
 Setting the SSLKEYLOGFILE environment variable to capture TLS session keys on target host Use netsh trace start to capture traffic (no need to install additional driver/software!
articles.title: Decrypting TLS browser traffic with Wireshark

articles.description: Up until recently, we've enjoyed in-memory loading of Mach-O bundles courtesy of dyld and its NSCreateObjectFileImageFromMemory/NSLinkModule API methods. And while these methods still exist today, there is a key difference.. memory modules are now persisted to disk. So in this post we'll take a look at just what was changed in dyld, and see what we can do to restore this functionality... hopefully keeping our warez in memory for a little longer.
articles.title: Restoring Dyld Memory Loading
